topic.title: Simple troubleshooting topic
topic.shortdesc: We cover a simple scenario that can be handled in a troubleshooting topic with a single cause and remedy pair. We will show both the rendered output, XML source, and writing best practices.

section.title: Scenario
section.p: In this example, we cover simple troubleshooting for a low-power consumer product that runs on household electricity. A single troubleSolution element can be used to document the corrective action.
The following information summarizes the problems that the user encounters:

ul.li: The system is plugged in, the power switch is on, but the system will not start.
This problem is external to the system, and it is almost always due to a tripped circuit breaker.

section.title: Writing best practices
section.p: The following table provides best practice information for the elements used in the simple troubleshooting topic:

strow.stentry: Describe the problem from the user's point of view. Describe the symptoms rather than the cause.
Everything looks right, but the system still does not start.

Use "Condition" for the title unless you have good reason to do something else. Be consistent from one troubleshooting topic to the next. Considering having your stylesheets add the title for the condition element.

Provide simple elaboration on what has already appeared in the topic title and short description. Only include information that is directly related to the condition or the symptom that the topic resolves.
The system is plugged in, the power switch is on, but the system will not start
Use "Cause" for the title unless you have good reason to do otherwise.
Describe only the origin of the problem that is resolved by the remedy.
The problem is usually due to the power not being supplied to the system through the electrical outlet. Often, a circuit breaker has been tripped so that no power is available at the outlet.
